interlinear-text.item: GSK Le Dive et la Fille du Roi

phrase.item: Once upon a time there was a king who had a daughter.
One day the king captured a flea and placed it in a house.
One day he slaughtered a sheep and gave it to the flea: it became the size of a sheep.
Another day he slaughtered a cow, gave it to the flea: it became the size of a cow. Next he slaughtered an elephant, gave it to the flea: it beame the size of an elephant.
Next he slaughtered it [the flea], placed its skin in the [town] square and said that he would offer his daughter's hand in marriage to whoever figures out what kind of skin it is.
Everyone came and said: "We will recognize where the skin is from"
but no one figured it out.
The princess had two servants
and at the edge of the river lived a madman.
The two servants went to get water and said: "Oh! how foolish these people are!
They don't know that it's the skin of a flea!"
The madman had been listening.
The servants took the water and went back; the madman made himself look human and began to shine like a torch.
He went near the skin
and said: "Why is this skin thrown here in the [town] square?"

They responded: "The king has a very beautiful daughter. He has placed this skin in the [town] square and said he would offer his daughter's hand in marriage to whoever recognizes what this skin is from."
The madman said: "The answer to the enigma is that the skin is from a flea."
Everyone applauded, the people were stunned.
The king was informed that a young man appeared, shining like a torch and he discovered that the particularity of this skin is that it's a flea's skin.
The king said: "I promised to give my daughter's hand to whoever identified this skin."
The king came and saw that the young man was handsome.
He said: "I will give you my daughter."
He [the madman] said: "Very good."
He left and called to his daughter.
But the daughter knew that he was a madman.
The king said to his daughter: "My dear daughter!
A young man has came, [and] he identified the flea skin.
I am going to give him your hand [in marriage], he's a very good boy."
Deep down inside she thought: "Yes, curse your father, he's a madman."
But out of respect for her father she didn't dare to say it.
The father organized the wedding on the spot, gave her hand in marriage to the madman and gave them a room in an independant (separate) house.
The princess said too her husband: "Until you bring me to your palace, I'm not sharing your bed with you."
The madman and the princess slept separately.
When day came, the young man went to say his goodbyes to the king.
The princess went up to her father and he was in the process of preparing all kinds of riches for her.
She said: "Father, I don't need your riches (wealth.)"
He said: "My dear daughter, what do you want then?"
She responded: "I don't need anything, but if you give me something, let it be the grey horse."
The father only had one thing left to do: he saddled up his grey horse and gave it to his daughter.
When she brought back the horse, the madman was overjoyed. The princess said: "Hey madman, let's go let's hit the road." They set off, crossed many deserts and grasslands and stopped in a plain.
But the madman really liked to sleep, right away he arranced his bed, layed down and slumber overtook him.
The young girl said to the grey horse: "Hey good horse!
Set me free from the claws of this madman!"
She dressed in masculin garments, put her foot in the stirrup, jumped onto the horse and struck him with her whip.
By the time the madman woke up, the horse had taken her far away.
He began to hit himself in the head but this did nothing to solve the issue.
She was wearing masculine clothes and no one could tell she was a woman.
The king went on a walk with his vizier: a young man is sitting under a tree, he is shining like torch.
He said: "Hey vizier if you take a young man like that with you, it would be very good.""
The king took him into the palace with him.
The vizier took him by his side so that he could aid him.
so that he could be of aid to him.
But the king had another vizier, [who was] very old, who said: "Hey king!
It's a woman."
He said: "No, vizier, it's a man"
The vizier said: "No, it's a woman."
The king asked: "How do we bring to light (disclose) that she is a woman?"
He said: "Take her to a goat (?) fight; if while falling she says "Oh God!"
You will know that that she's a woman, if she doesn't say "Oh God!"
and gets up with with ease, you'll know that he's a man."
In the morning, when they took her to the goat (?) fight, she didn't fall.
The king said: "Hey vizier, didn't I tell you he was a man?"
And you said: "She's a woman."
He responded: "No, she's a woman, but [a] very intelligent [one."
The vizier said: "Take a sac of millet, scatter it out on the ground and tell the [horse] grooms to shout out during the night: "Hey vizier, your grey horse got loose!"
If, while worrying about her horse, she rushes and falls on the millet, you'll know that she's a woman, if she doesn't fall you'll know that he's a man."
He scattered a sac of millet on the ground and said to the grooms: "Tonight yell out: "Hey vizier, your horse got loose!"
The grooms spread the millet on the ground and, once the princess was sleeping, they began shouting: "Hey vizier!
Your grey horse got loose!"
In the morning the king summoned her and said: "Yes, apparently you're a woman." [Some sentences are missing before this one.]
She said: "No, I am a man."
The king said: "Tomorrow we go to the bath." She said: "O king, I am the the daughter of a king, I was married to a king's son.
We reached a plain and the king's son died.
I buried him and I put on this masculine garment that you see here, I arrived and stopped in your city."
The king took her as a wife, and she was overjoyed that he didn't know of the existance of the madman.
The princess said to him: "I'll give you a daughter with golden curls and a son with golden curls. "
As the delivery date [of the baby] grew nearer, the king randomly went out to the street and in the street there was a young man.
He said: "Hey young man, what is your profession?"
The king took him as a miller, set him up at the mill, and he adjusted it so well that it began milling one hundred 'cires' (?) per day.
The king said: "Hey, wife, I am going for a ride, let me take your grey horse."
The princess said to him said to him: "Hey king, firstly you aren't allowed to go away, the final month has arrived and if you leave,
one could harm me."
He said: "Hey, who will harm you?"
She said: "When you leave, don't take my grey [horse]." The king got upset and she gave him the grey horse.
She said: "Oh king, do not take my reigns or my whip, or my straps, or my saddle pad.
I will give you one more piece of advice: if my horse becomes sad and lowers his ears, let him go on the spot." The king left and she brought a son and daughter into the world.
She announced to the vizier: "The king is father to a daughter with golden curls and to a son with golden curls."
The vizier wrote a letter to the king to tell him that a son with golden curls and a daughter with golden curls were born to him.
He gave it to a man to deliver this happy news to the king.
When this man reached the mill, the madman was standing nearr the mill and asked him: "Hey man!
Where are you going?"
He said: "I am delivering news to the king that a daughter with gold curls and a son with gold curls were born to him."
He said: "Come inside, eat a slice (piece) of warm koumotch and then go!"
When he entered the mill, the madman gave him datura (a poison plant) and he fell out of consciousness.
The madman took the letter, [and] wrote that the king was father to a dog and a cat.

He slipped his letter into the pocket of the messenger and he burned the letter written by the vizier that had tajen took. He [the madman] made him [the messenger] inhale a drug in order for him to regain consciousness, it came back, he got up and set off once again on the road with his letter.
He [the messenger] arrived near the king.
When he gave this letter to the king, the king read that a dog and a cat were born to him.
The king wrote a letter to his vizier: "Until my return, my wife is to be obeyed [just] like me."
The messenger took this letter and when he reached the mill, once again the madman diverted him from his path: "Come eat koumotch!"

Once again the messenger entered the mill, [and] once again the madman gave him datura and once again he fell out of consciousness. The madman took the letter and read what the king wrote: "Until my return, my wife is to be obeyed by the vizier [just] like me."
The madman also burned this letter and wrote another one: "Put my wife and her children on a blind donkey and chase (drive) them out of the city."
The messenger regained consiousness, got up, set off again, brought back the letter, [and] delivered it to the vizier.
The vizier read: "Put my wife on a blind donkey and chase (drive) her and her children out of the city!"
After having read the letter the vizier said: "Bring a blind donkey!"
In the court a blind black donkey rolls in 'pargichyne.' (It's the madman that has taken form of the donkey and is rolling in 'pargichyne.')
The vizier said: "Do not go any farther to find a donkey, there is one right here.
Bring it here, [and] place her and the children on it at the same time (together).
Chase (drive) them all out of the city!"
They brought over the blind donkey, placed the king's wife on it as well as her kids.
The princess took her reigns, her saddle pad, her straps, put them on the donkey, shoved the bridle in its mouth and this donkey, snorting (OR reluctantly), took them out of the city."
When the donkey brought them out of the city he said: "Hey princess!
Well now you have fallen into my hands, yes or no?"
She said: "This is my destiny."
They reached the edge of a river, dismounted; the river was very wide.
Once again sleep overtook the madman, slumber took hold of him.
And the princess began crying and whining (wimpering): "If only my grey [horse] could appear!"
What's "tob"? (Doesn't appear in dictionary)
She thought: "If my horse doesn't appear, I will throw myself in this river with the children."
She lifted her head, dust rose from the steppe; Shortly after the grey horse appeared: the king had let it go and the horse began galloping towards the princess.
The grey [horse] said: "Pass me the bridle."
She put the reigns on him, put the saddle pad on him, buckled his straps and he said: "Take your children and sit down!"
She took her kids and sat on the horse.
She made him cross the river, [and she] looked back: the madman had awoken and threw himself in the river.
The horse said: "Oh princess!
Like the madman I am going to throw myself in the river, if black blood appears, be calm, I will have killed the madman; if it's red blood that appears, throw yourself in the river too."
Nominative transitive subject in "I will have killed the madman".
Soon after, red blood appeared.
The princess brought her children towards the water's edge.
A bit more time passed and black blood appeared and filled the river.
She said: "My grey has killed the madman."
And again a bit later the grey horse came out and said: "Hey princess, when the red blood appeared, I had hit my leg against a stone, this is where the red blood came from.
Now take a knife, slice my head [off] and a terrible tempest (storm) will be unleashed.
Open up my belly, take my intestines and disperse them here.
Slide yourself into my skin.
The princess said: "I don't have enough courage to slice off your head."
He responded: "I am allowing you to." She said: "I don't have my knife on me."
He said: "Your knife is behind my ear."
She took the knife, sliced off his head, opened up his stomach, [and] dispersed the intestines.
She slid herself inside, covered herself with the skin and thus the storm began.
She fell asleep inside this skin.
They spent the night, in the morning got up: stands such a [grand]citadel that reason falters (shocking/doesn't make sense): what is this miracle?
They saw that all of the intestines that she scattered had transformed into grey horses.
She stayed in this citadelle (castle.)
The king came back from his trip: no wife.
He said: "Hey vizier!
Where is my wife?"
The vizier responded: " You wrote me a letter [saying]: " Put my wife on a blind donkey, and chase her out of the city."
He said: "Hey vizier!"
Curse your father and what you're saying now!"
The king left his kingdom, dressed in kalandar's clothing and set off.
He crossed many plains and deserts and reached the edge of the river.
He crossed the river on a boat and continued on his way.
Once again he crossed many plains and deserts and reached the citadelle where is wife was; as for his kids with golden curls, they had grown.
They went and said to their mother: " An old man is standing in front of our door."
The king's wife went out: it was the king in person.
She said to them: "Oh children, it's your father."
They responded: "We have no use for such a father!"
She said: "Children, there is nothing more shameful than rejecting your father!"
The king's daughter presented him with such tributes that tears rolled down the king's cheeks.
The princess asked him: "Hey kalandar!
Why are there tears rolling down your cheeks?"
He said: "I had a wife with a face identitcal to yours.
I left on a journey; when I returned I heard that she had brought brought a son with golden curls and a daughter with golden curls into the world.
The vizier wrote me a letter saying: "A cat and a dog were born to you."
I wrote him a letter so that unril my return, he would obey her just like me.
When I returned, it turned out that the vizier had put her [his wife] on a blind donkey and chased her out of the city.
So I put on kalandar clothing; now I'm searching for her, this is why I told you: 'with a face identical to yours.'
She said: "It's me in person."
The king was overjoyed and became young once again.
They embraced and lived happily ever after on the throne, with their children.
